Headline: Bangladeshi PM Sheikh Hasina resigns as widening unrest sees protesters storm her.
Summary: Jenna Ellis to cooperate in Arizona fake electors case, charges to be dropped. Bangladesh’s prime minister has resigned and fled the country, after weeks of protests. Violence just before and after her resignation left at least 41 people dead and about 200 others injured. At least 11,000 people have been arrested in recent weeks in a crackdown that has left nearly 300 people dead since mid-July. The military wields significant political influence in Bangladesh, which has faced more than 20 coups or coup attempts since independence in 1971.. Tropical Storm Debby slams Florida with torrential rain, high winds and flooding, contributing to at least five deaths. Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 index has soared more than 10% after it set markets tumbling. The only thing missing from this week's campaign blitz is the name of Kamala Harris and her 2024 running mate.

Headline: Several U.S. personnel were injured in a suspected rocket attack at Al Asad air base.
Summary: Several U S personnel were injured in a suspected rocket attack at a military base in Iraq. No critical injuries, such as a loss of limbs, have been reported at this time, and no service members were killed. The attack comes amid extremely high tensions in the Middle East. The US has been bracing for Iranian retaliation against Israel over the assassination of Hamas political leader Ismail Haniyeh in Tehran last week. Both groups are backed by Iran, and Iranian-backed Iraqi militias have resumed launching attacks on bases housing U S forces in Iraq and Syria. The strike occurs amidst escalating tensions throughout the Mideast, following the recent assassinations of a high-ranking Hezbollah commander in Lebanon and the top political leader of Hamas in Iran. US President Joe Biden spoke with Jordan’s King Abdullah on Monday in a bid to head off the expected Iranian attack.

Headline: Nine UNRWA staff will be fired for potential role in the 7 October attacks on Israel.
Summary: UN Office of Oversight Services (OIOS) launched investigation earlier this year. OIOS was not able to independently authenticate information used by Israel to support the allegations. Israel has long accused UNR WA of collaborating with Hamas and turning a blind eye to the militant group's activities during the 10-month old Gaza war. About 1,200 people were killed and 251 others were taken back to Gaza as hostages in the unprecedented assault last autumn. UN did not provide details on what actions the employees may have carried out, but noted that they would be fired from their roles. The investigation’s conclusion appeared to bring to a close, for now at least, a controversy that began after Israel leveled the alarming accusations in January. The allegations led dozens of donor nations to suspend hundreds of millions of dollars in funding for the agency.

Headline: Iran has decided to attack Israel, Foreign Minister Katz says.
Summary: US CENTCOM Commander Gen. Michael Erik Kurilla visited Israel on Monday and met with Defense Minister Yoav Gallant and IDF Chief of Staff Lt -Gen Herzi Halevi. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken spoke to Qatari Prime Minister Al Thani and Egyptian Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty about the situation. US President Joe Biden was expected to meet Monday afternoon with his national security team to discuss the situation Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian said Tehran was determined to expand relations with its “strategic partner Russia,” Iranian state media reported.US Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned his G7 counterparts that that an attack by Iran and Hezbollah against Israel could start as early as Monday. Iran's message was delivered to Israel through Hungary's Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó. This comes amid the military's call-up of hundreds of haredim for enlistment. Ireland, Spain, and Norway on Wednesday said they will officially recognize a Palestinian state. Israel wasted no time in excoriating the decision, which was met with a predictably furious response by Israel as it faces mounting international condemnation.

Headline: UK prime minister talks of a ‘standing army’ of police to deal with riots.
Summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer says justice system will be ramped up to handle hundreds of arrests. Starmer blames lawlessness on ‘far-right thuggery’ driven in part by misinformation on social media. More than 375 people have been arrested in the mayhem so far and more are expected, police say. Dozens of police officers have been hospitalized for injuries in the past six days after being struck with bricks, bottles and large wooden posts.Violence is the worst England has seen since 2011, when widespread rioting followed the police killing of a mixed-race man.Names and addresses of solicitors’ firms and advice agencies shared in list of locations to be targeted by demonstrators. Police patrols are being stepped up in Teesside over the coming days amid fears the area could be hit with more violent disorder. Charity that helps refugees has been forced to close its headquarters in Liverpool after receiving threats of far-right violence. Five countries have issued travel alerts following almost a week of rioting. Prime Minister has faced calls from Nigel Farage, among others, to recall Parliament to discuss the response to the disorder. Police have made 378 arrests since violence broke out last week.

Headline: Venezuela’s top prosecutor announces a criminal probe of opposition leaders.
Summary: The opposition claims to have collected records from more than 80% of the 30,000 polling booths nationwide showing it won. Maduro announced Saturday that the government has arrested 2,000 opponents and pledged to detain more people. Pressure is also building internationally for the Venezuelan government to publish the full breakdown of the electoral results. But so far, Maduro has instead asked the country’s supreme court — which like all institutions in Venezuela is packed with loyalists — to review any claims of irregularities. The armed forces are traditionally the arbiter of political disputes in Venezuela and have shown no signs of ditching Maduro.Brazil's President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva and Chile's Gabriel Boric cast doubt on Maduro's victory claim. Authorities have declared Maduro the victor in last week's election but have yet to produce voting tallies to prove he won. The opposition claims to have collected records from more than 80 per cent of the country's 30,000 polling booths, showing it won. Maduro announced Saturday that the government had arrested 2,000 opponents, and at a rally in Caracas, he pledged to detain more people. A few of Maduro's staunch allies — including Russia, China and Cuba — have applauded his victory.

Headline: Ukraine’s Zelenskyy displays newly arrived F-16 fighter jets.
Summary: Ukraine destroyed a Russian Su-34 fighter-bomber aircraft and ammunition depot at an airfield some 165 miles from the frontline of the war. The attack on the Morozovsk airfield in Russia’s Rostov region on Saturday is also likely to have damaged two other Su- 34 warplanes. It came as Volodymyr Zelensky unveiled the first Western-supplied F-16 warplanes to arrive in Ukraine, and asked for Nato allies to help protect them. Putin has warned that Moscow could consider launching strikes at facilities in Nato countries if they host the warplanes used in Ukraine. Belgium, Denmark, the Netherlands and Norway have committed to providing Ukraine with more than 60 of them.Belgium, Denmark, the Netherlands and Norway have pledged to deliver more than 60 F- 16s to bolster Ukraine's air defences. The fighter jet is equipped with a 20mm cannon and can carry bombs, rockets and missiles. Ukraine is also trying to get neighboring countries to help defend it against Russian missiles. Poland had promised Ukraine four MiG-29 fighter jets, which had been inherited from the former German Democratic Republic. Russia has warned that Moscow could consider launching strikes at facilities in NATO countries if they host the warplanes used in Ukraine.

Headline: U.S. troops withdraw from strategic West African base as militant threat grows.
Summary: Nigerien Prime Minister Ali Mahaman Lamine Zeine blamed the breakdown on the United States. The U S presence here has been a linchpin of American efforts to address rising Islamist militancy in this part of Africa. In Niger, the Africa Center projects 1,230 deaths related to Islamist violence this year. The withdrawal undermines U S strategy not only for Niger but for the Sahel region, a U S official says. It marks a strategic defeat for the U S at a moment when the Islamist extremist threat in the region is growing.. Hundreds of angry people took to the streets in Pakistan-administered Kashmir Monday to mark the fifth anniversary of India's decision to strip the disputed region of its semi-autonomy. A new crop of Palestinian fighters, organizing loosely under an umbrella group, now patrols entrances to the camp.

Headline: Mali severs diplomatic relations with Ukraine for providing intelligence to rebels for the Wagner ambush.
Summary: Mali has severed diplomatic relations with Ukraine following allegations that Ukrainian intelligence assisted Malian rebels in a deadly ambush against Wagner Group forces in July. At least 84 mercenaries and 47 Malian soldiers were killed by The northern Tuareg rebels and fighters linked to Al-qaeda in July north of the West African country. This is the largest loss of the Wagner PMC in all the years of its presence in Africa. Meanwhile, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov reaffirmed support for Mali in a recent call with Malian Foreign Minister Abdoulaye Diop. Mali also cited comments by Ukraine’s Ambassador to Senegal Yurii Pyvovarov, who was summoned by Senegal over a video published on Facebook in which he provided “unequivocal and unqualified support for the terrorist attack” Mali said it would break off relations “with immediate effect”

Headline: Israel returns bodies of over 80 Palestinians to Gaza, keeps up military pressure.
Summary: International Criminal Court’s prosecutor says reports of rapes, crimes against children and persecution on a massive scale continue to be fueled by the “provision of arms, financial support from various sectors” US Border Patrol announced that Debby had washed up 25 packages of cocaine to the coast of the Florida Keys, where they were seized. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Monday urged all sides in the Middle East to avoid “escalation’ US President Joe Biden held crisis talks on Monday with his national security team, an Israeli military statement said.. Yemen-aligned Houthis say they targeted the Liberia-flagged MV Groton in the Gulf of Aden with ballistic missiles, claiming their first attack on shipping lanes since Israel carried out a retaliatory airstrike in Hodeidah port on July 20.
